reference: Berg Å., 1997. Diversity and abundance of birds in relation to forest fragmentation, habitat quality and heterogeneity. Bird Study, 44, pp.355-366
intensity: Entire fragment or large plot censing
sampling_effort_unit: area of the sites in ha
sampling_note: Territory mapping for all but colony breeders.  Numbers of each species were mapped from the entire fragment or from a discretized area within large or continous forests that was deliminted by roads, etc.  Large continuous forests were listed as >1000, and given a value of 1000 here.

reference: Bernard, E. & Fenton, M.B., 2007. Bats in a fragmented landscape: Species composition, diversity and habitat interactions in savannas of Santarém, Central Amazonia, Brazil. Biological Conservation, 134(3), pp.332-343.
sampling_density: total net time given in sampling_effort
sampling_note: Between April-December 2000.  Mist nets set along transects in each site.  Length of mist nets and time varied, each site was sampled 3-5 times.  For each site, total net hours per site are given as effort and captures for each site are totalled.  Only forest samples were included, not savannah.

For each site, total net hours per site are given as effort and captures for each site are totalled.  Only forest samples were included, not savannah.

reference: Bernard, E. & Fenton, M.B., 2007. Bats in a fragmented landscape: Species composition, diversity and habitat interactions in savannas of Santarém, Central Amazonia, Brazil. Biological Conservation, 134(3), pp.332-343.

reference: Bolger, D.T. et al., 1997. Response of rodents to habitat fragmentation in caostal southern California. Ecological Applications, 7(2), pp.552-563.
sampling_note: Live trapping of small mammals in Californian canyons considered as fragments. Each canyon had been sampled two to five times depending on its size. The number of traplines and their length depended on the size and shape of each canyon. Traplines were set latitudinally, from an edge to the other. Traplines were set 100 m apart from each other and Sherman traps were set 2 m apart. October 86 to May 87.

reference: Dixo, M. & Metzger, J.P., 2009. Are corridors, fragment size and forest structure important for the conservation of leaf-litter lizards in a fragmented landscape? Oryx, 43(3), p.435.
sampling_note: Traplines placed along a transect in each fragment with 11 bucket traps and a drift fence.  Numbers are total caught.

reference: Dominguez-Haydar, Y. & Armbrecht, I., 2011. Response of Ants and Their Seed Removal in Rehabilitation Areas and Forests at El Cerrejón Coal Mine in Colombia. Restoration Ecology, 19(201), pp.178-184.
sampling_note: Ants sampled 3 times in each site between 2006 and 2009.  Each sampling consisted of 100 m transects with 10 equidistant sampling stations (pitfall traps).  Data are for 2 of the intact forests (a 3rd was missing) and does not include samples from restored forests.

reference: Dominguez-Haydar, Y. & Armbrecht, I., 2011. Response of Ants and Their Seed Removal in Rehabilitation Areas and Forests at El Cerrejón Coal Mine in Colombia. Restoration Ecology, 19(201), pp.178-184.

reference: Echeverría, C. et al., 2007. Impacts of forest fragmentation on species composition and forest structure in the temperate landscape of southern Chile. Global Ecology and Biogeography, 16(4), pp.426-439.
intensity_unit: contiguous 5 m * 5 m subplots per plot
sampling_note: Variable numbers of plots sampled.  Data presented are means from a number of fragments standardized to numbers per ha.  Sizes were taken as averages of plots.

reference: Edwards, D.P. et al., 2010. Wildlife-friendly oil palm plantations fail to protect biodiversity effectively. Conservation Letters, 3(4), pp.236-242.
intensity_unit: minutes listening per point per survey day
density_unit: stations per transect in fragments and contiguous forest sites respectively
duration_unit: sampling days in fragments and consecutive forest sites respectively
sampling_note: In each site, birds were sampled by walking 6 transects for 15 min using timed point-counts with an unlimited radius at stations.  Only data from forest fragments were included, not from oil palm.

reference: Estrada, A. & Coates-Estrada, R., 2002. Bats in continuous forest, forest fragments and in an agricultural mosaic habitat-island at Los Tuxtlas, Mexico. Biological Conservation, 103, pp.237-245.
duration_unit: survey periods of two nights per year during 3 years
sampling_note: 16 locations within continuous forest were sampled, along with 16 separate fragments.  Sampling occurred 3 times over 3 years (1997-1999), and consisted of a line of fifteen 12 m long mist nets.  Sampling was equivalent in each patch.  Data for sampling in agricultural areas not included.

reference: Estrada, A. & Coates-Estrada, R., 2002. Bats in continuous forest, forest fragments and in an agricultural mosaic habitat-island at Los Tuxtlas, Mexico. Biological Conservation, 103, pp.237-245.
site_id: Forest fragments (range from 1-80 ha average=13 ha)
duration_unit: survey periods of two nights per year during 3 years
sampling_note: 16 locations within continuous forest were sampled, along with 16 separate fragments. reference: Estrada, A. & Coates-Estrada, R., 2002. Dung beetles in continuous forest, forest fragments and in an agricultural mosaic habitat island at Los Tuxtlas, Mexico. Biodiversity and Conservation, 11(11), pp.1903-1918.
sampling_note: 50 baited pitfall traps (10-15 m intervals) in 16 locations within continuous forest and in one location in each of 16 fragments.   A total of 288 trap days between 1997 and 1999.  Data from agricultural sites not included.

reference: Estrada, A. & Coates-Estrada, R., 2002. Dung beetles in continuous forest, forest fragments and in an agricultural mosaic habitat island at Los Tuxtlas, Mexico. Biodiversity and Conservation, 11(11), pp.1903-1918.

reference: Jung, J.K. et al., 2014. A comparison of diversity and species composition of ground beetles (Coleoptera: Carabidae) between conifer plantations and regenerating forests in Korea. Ecological Research, 29(5), pp.877-887.
sampling_note: Pitfall traps (30 m from edge).  Three traps 10 m apart in a transect in each site.   Natural (regenerating) forest plots were used but not the coniferous monoculture plots.  Sites listed as >1000 ha were coded as 1000 ha.

reference: Kappes, H. et al., 2009. Response of snails and slugs to fragmentation of lowland forests in NW Germany. Landscape Ecology, 24(5), pp.685-697.
sampling_note: At each site, one or more grids of 8 samples (0.125m2).  Samples were leaf litter samples which were systematically searched for molluscs.  In addition, rare species were observed outside the quadrats and added as 'decimals' based on search effort.

reference: Mac Nally, R. & Brown, G., 2001. Reptiles and habitat fragmentation in the box-ironbark forests of central Victoria, Australia: predictions, compositional change and faunal nestedness. Oecologia, 128, pp.128-116.
sampling_note: Only data from pitfall traps and visual surveys (intensive) in central Dunolly forest block were used (too few individuals or species observed in transects per fragment at other sites).  Ten pitfall traps set in each fragment and opened for given periods of time across the sample period.  Samples taken during 1995-1997.  Second method was 2 active searches of one 10 m * 25 m per fragment per summer for 2 summers.

reference: Mac Nally, R. & Brown, G., 2001. Reptiles and habitat fragmentation in the box-ironbark forests of central Victoria, Australia: predictions, compositional change and faunal nestedness. Oecologia, 128, pp.128-116.
sampling_note: Only data from pitfall traps and visual surveys (intensive) in central Dunolly forest block were used (too few individuals or species observed in transects per fragment at other sites).  Ten pitfall traps set in each fragment and opened for given periods of time across the sample period.  Samples taken during 1995-1997.  Second method was 2 active searches of one 10 m * 25 m per fragment per summer for 2 summers.

reference: Mac Nally, R. & Brown, G., 2001. Reptiles and habitat fragmentation in the box-ironbark forests of central Victoria, Australia: predictions, compositional change and faunal nestedness. Oecologia, 128, pp.128-116.

Ten pitfall traps set in each fragment and opened for given periods of time across the sample period.  Samples taken during 1995-1997.  Second method was 2 active searches of one 10 m * 25 m per fragment per summer for 2 summers.

reference: McIntyre, N.E., 1995. Effects of forest patch size on avian diversity. Landscape Ecology, 10(2), pp.85-99.
intensity_unit: m long 40 m wide transect explored in ca. 20 minutes per fragment
sampling_note: In each patch, sampled 100 m * 40 m transect over approximately 20 min.  Each patch was sampled 10 times between January and April 1993.  Data provided are averages for each fragment type.

reference: McIntyre, N.E., 1995. Effects of forest patch size on avian diversity. Landscape Ecology, 10(2), pp.85-99.
intensity_unit: m long 40 m wide transect explored in ca. 20 minutes per fragment

reference: McIntyre, N.E., 1995. Effects of forest patch size on avian diversity. Landscape Ecology, 10(2), pp.85-99.
intensity_unit: m long 40 m wide transect explored in ca. 20 minutes per fragment
sampling_note: In each patch, sampled 100 m * 40 m transect over approximately 20 min.  Each patch was sampled 10 times between January and April 1993.  Data provided are averages for each fragment type.

reference: Meyer, C.F.J., Kalko, E.K.V., 2008a. Assemblage-level responses of phyllostomid bats to tropical forest fragmentation: land-bridge islands as a model system. Journal of Biogeography, 35, pp.1711-1726.

reference: Paciencia, M.L.B. & Prado, J., 2005. Effects of forest fragmentation on pteridophyte diversity in a tropical rain forest in Brazil. Plant Ecology, 180(1), pp.87-104.
sampling_effort_unit: number of fragment per size category
sampling_note: In each site, one 0.12 ha plot was sampled for all pteridophytes up to 1 m above ground.  Number of sampling sites differed between fragment sizes.  Only 'core' samples were used, not edges.  Sizes of <100 ha were given 100, and >900 were given 900 for conservatism.

reference: Paciencia, M.L.B. & Prado, J., 2005. Effects of forest fragmentation on pteridophyte diversity in a tropical rain forest in Brazil. Plant Ecology, 180(1), pp.87-104.
sampling_effort_unit: number of fragment per size category
sampling_note: In each site, one 0.12 ha plot was sampled for all pteridophytes up to 1 m above ground.  Number of sampling sites differed between fragment sizes.  Only 'core' samples were used, not edges.  Sizes of <100 ha were given 100, and >900 were given 900 for conservatism.

reference: Pardini, R., 2004. Effects of forest fragmentation on small mammals in an Atlantic Forest landscape. Biodiversity and Conservation, 13(13), pp.2567-2586.
intensity_unit: live trap stations per 165 m long transect
duration_unit: days trapping per site for live traps and pitfall traps respectively
sampling_note: Two 165 m transects with multiple live trap sizes and pitfalls.  Live trap stations are constituted of one large and one small Sherman traps.  Three capture sessions of 7 days each.  Numbers are averages per site (6 sites within each category).  Edges were not included.  Sites denoted as >1000 ha were given 1000 ha, and <100 ha were given 100 ha for conservatism.

reference: Pardini, R., 2004. Effects of forest fragmentation on small mammals in an Atlantic Forest landscape. Biodiversity and Conservation, 13(13), pp.2567-2586.

reference: Sam K., Koane B., Jeppy S., & Novotny V., 2014. Effect of forest fragmentation on bird species richness in Papua New Guinea. Journal of Field Ornithology, 85, pp.152-167.
method_category: point count and mist nets and random walk
device_size_unit: m long net in total for 6 days of 12 hours per fragment
intensity_unit: points of 15 minutes each per 2250 m transect
sampling_note: Several sampling methods combined.  Point counts (16 points along a 2250 m transect), mist netting (200 m, one per site) and random walks within 80 ha study plot.  Thus sampling approximately equal among plots.

sampling_note: Several sampling methods combined.  Point counts (16 points along a 2250 m transect), mist netting (200 m, one per site) and random walks within 80 ha study plot.  Thus sampling approximately equal among plots.

reference: Savilaakso, S., Koivisto, J., Veteli, T.O. and Roininen, H., 2009. Microclimate and tree community linked to differences in lepidopteran larval communities between forest fragments and continuous forest.  Diversity and Distributions,  15(2), pp.356-365.
intensity_unit: m diameter plots in large fragments and continuous forest but whole fragment assessment for small fragments
density_unit: plots per site in LN and continuous forest only
sampling_note: All individuals in smallest fragments counted.  Largest fragment and continuous forest, 8 circular plots with 20 m diameter counted.  Abundances given are numbers per hectare.

reference: Silveira, G.C., Freitas, R.F., Tosta, T.H.A., Rabelo, L.S., Gaglianone, M.C. and Augusto, S.C., 2015. The orchid bee fauna in the Brazilian savanna: do forest formations contribute to higher species diversity? Apidologie, 46, pp.197-208.
sampling_note: Male euglossine bees sampled in the morning each month for a year.  Traps baited with seven aromatic compounds.  Individuals that did not enter the traps were captured with an entomological net.  Fragment 1 (2008-2009), Fragment 2 (2008-2009), Fragment 3 (2010-2011), Fragment 4 (2010-2011), Fragment 5 (2012-2013).

reference: Tellería, J.L. & Santos, T., 1995. Effects of forest fragmentation on a guild of wintering passerines: The role of habitat selection. Biological Conservation, 71(1), pp.61-67.
intensity_unit: m wide transects in large fragments and whole fragment search for small fragments
sampling_note: Birds were intensively searched in the entire fragment (small fragments) and 25 m strips along transects (large fragments).  Data converted to numbers per 10 ha.  Averages were taken of density and fragment size.

reference: Uehara-Prado, M., Brown, K.S. & Freitas, A.V.L., 2007. Species richness, composition and abundance of fruit-feeding butterflies in the Brazilian Atlantic Forest: Comparison between a fragmented and a continuous landscape. Global Ecology and Biogeography, 16(1), pp.43-54.
number_of_blocks_per_site: 1 per fragment or 4 in the continuous forest site
sampling_note: Each site received a sampling unit consisting of 5 baited traps (20 m apart) along a transect.  Sampling effort differed because there were 4 sites in the continuous forest and 5 fragments.

reference: Uehara-Prado, M., Brown, K.S. & Freitas, A.V.L., 2007. Species richness, composition and abundance of fruit-feeding butterflies in the Brazilian Atlantic Forest: Comparison between a fragmented and a continuous landscape. Global Ecology and Biogeography, 16(1), pp.43-54.
number_of_blocks_per_site: 1 per fragment or 4 in the continuous forest site

reference: Ulrich, W., Lens, L., Tobias, J.A. and Habel, J.C., 2016. Contrasting patterns of species richness and functional diversity in bird communities of east African cloud forest fragments. PLoS ONE 11,  e0163338.
sampling_note: Abundances collected from mist netting over 15 years.  Mist nets varied in sampling intensity to account for differences in fragment size.  It is not entirely clear that sampling was complete in each fragment, but it appears approximately proportional to area.

reference: Usher M.B. & Keiller S.W.J., 1998. The macrolepidoptera of farm woodlands: Determinants of diversity and community structure. Biodiversity and Conservation, 7, pp.725-748.
duration_unit: trap weeks of 3 trap nights each
sampling_note: Fragments sampled with 4 black light traps for 3 nights in a given week.  Fragments were divided into quarters and traps placed randomly in a given quarter.  Sampling was approximately constant in each fragment.

reference: Vallan, D., 2000. Influence of forest fragmentation on amphibian diversity in the nature reserve of Ampohitantely, highland Madagaskar. Biological Conservation, 96, pp.31-43.
sampling_note: Each fragment was searched systematically during the day and night.  Larger fragments were surveyed more, but this was not proportional to size.  Authors stated that sampling ranged from 22 hours in the smallest and 90 hours in the largest.  These were taken as two extremes and search time for other fragments was interpolated.

reference: Vasconcelos, H.L., Vilhena, J.M., Magnusson, W.E. & Albernaz, A.L.M., 2006. Long-term effects of forest fragmentation on Amazonian ant communities.  Journal of Biogeography,  33(8), pp.1348-1356.
sampling_note: Only data from bait traps used for number estimates as quantitative estimates of abundance could be gained (percent of bait traps occupied).  40 bait traps per site, every 25 m alternatively on ground and in vegetation.  If a species was present in the other survey types (Winkler, transect), it is given an *, which should be 0 for quantitative surveys, but 1 for any presence-absence analyses.

reference: Vasconcelos, H.L., Vilhena, J.M., Magnusson, W.E. & Albernaz, A.L.M., 2006. Long-term effects of forest fragmentation on Amazonian ant communities.  Journal of Biogeography,  33(8), pp.1348-1356.

If a species was present in the other survey types (Winkler, transect), it is given an *, which should be 0 for quantitative surveys, but 1 for any presence-absence analyses.

reference: Zartman, C.E., 2003. Habitat Fragmentation Impacts on Epiphyllous Bryophyte Communities in Central Amazonia. Ecology, 84(4), pp.948-954.
intensity:
Number of sampled branches is proportional to the
estimated abundances of epiphylls in each plot
density_unit: plots per site as follow 2 100ha 3 1 ha and 10 ha and 8 plots in continuous forest
sampling_effort_unit: area in ha sampled per fragment
sampling_note: Randomly collected entire branch from host plants in 1 ha plots within fragments.  Three plots in 1 and 10 ha plots, two in 100 ha plots.  Randomly collected branches from 0.52 ha * 8 plots in continuous forest.  Sample effort is the total.

sampling_note: Two 100 m long transects in each fragment.  Along each, 5 10 * 10 m plots were sampled, for a total of 10 plots per fragment.
